reviewText:
Just like Team Fortress and Counter-Strike, this was once merely a Half-Life mod that Gabe Newell and his co-workers decided to put some extra effort into. It became a high-end standalone title, and brother, did they make a good job. Improved textures, mechanics and overall level design.

The game is pretty simple at its core; it's a elimination/free-for-all game where you have to use your surroundings, levels and weapon - the power disc - to claim yourself the big name of the game. Moving fast and swiftly between platforms in a blitz of your enemies is vital for succession in this game. It takes some time to learn, and even longer to master. But by studying your opponents, you'll pick up their tricks soon enough and give them a taste of their own medicine.

One thing that I love about this game is the amount of servers that are available, over a decade after the game's release. You'll never have to wait for a server without open slots, allowing you to easily invite your friends to play with you. Trust me, this game is much more fun with your friends. The more players who join, the better and more intense the game becomes.

In conclusion, I think this game is extremely underrated and truly deserves a sequel. Lots of Valve fans seem to have forgotten about this gem, and even Valve themselves don't feature it on their official website. But I'm living proof that this game is still taking breaths. Forgotten but not lost, this game deserves your love. It's a part of the CS1 Anthology and the Valve Complete Pack, so chances are that you already have this game and simply forgot that you have it. Otherwise, it's available for the low price of $4.99 here on Steam (50% off as I'm writing).

And yes, the graphics might not live up to today's standards. But when games like Minecraft sells millions of copies, I don't see how graphics are an relevant issue.

Oh, a final tip to those who'll try this game out: don't fall.

9/10 (Would buy this game for a friend.)

reviewText:
A lesser known game among Steam (and also a definite buy if it's under a buck).

Ricochet is one of those games you buy on an extreme sale, play for probably 20 minutes to half hour at a time, then leave it for a while. Doesn't mean it's a bad game.

Ricochet's game mechanics revolves around simple movement. The player can move side to side, back and forth but can easily fall off the platform they are on. Players are meant to jump platform to platform, but are only able to by stepping on the arrows at the edge of the platform. The arrows then launch the player into the air and towards another platform. A player in the meantime, can jump at the same time you can and both of you can end up colliding, falling into an abyss of darkness. Or, one player can hit the right mouse button and kill the other guy with a Frisbee The player has the ability to shoot a disk to decapitate the opponent. Some of the maps I have played so far are quite intriguing, but don't offer any significant background to gaze at.

It's quite a simple game, and you basically are going to get what you pay for. Servers aren't always full, but I've been fortunate enough at the times that I do jump on (Saturday during the day) that they are. Graphics and sounds aren't anywhere near today's capabilities, but if you are one to enjoy a good game concept and can stand old graphics, this game is for you.Rating for it back in 2000, 7.5/10

reviewText:
Ricochet, I wouldn’t really label it under being a hidden gem or obscure. I mean come on it’s made by Valve, anything by Valve is known to a certain degree. But it is definitely underrated, people always shut down this game because it looks weird and or that it feels empty.

Valve certainly doesn’t seem to like it, they pay no attention at all to it and made it worth extra less in the summer sale and didn’t even talk about it in their backlog of old games which has the description of “Eleven games that changed the world, and one that didn’t.”... It’s Valve’s first game that was aimed towards being competitive and also isn’t related to Half-Life.

The game’s art-style is obviously derived from Tron, and takes place in some futuristic space planet arena thing. Regardless it’s actually pretty cool. And all the sound effects are unique and satisfying, except I swear the sound when you freeze somebody with a freeze shot is the sound of two lightsabers hitting each other.

The game unfortunately has no music of any sorts, I joked about this in a video where it was titled the full soundtrack to Ricochet but it was just an hour of nothing. But this game really could have used some ambience or something.

Anyway, the gameplay consists of switching through small floating platforms by launching yourself from a jump pad and throwing projectiles at other players and making them bounce off walls and such to either push them into the endless void below or to instantly kill them with a decapitation shot.
You can get powerups that power your discs such as rapid-fire, triple shots, power shots that decapitate, and freeze shots that can home in on other players. That last one may sound overpowered but it’s actually the worst.

The game has three maps as followed: Arena, deathmatch, and deathmatch 2. Arena is the more competitive 1v1 map while deathmatch and deathmatch 2 are more for, well, deathmatches with multiple players.

And that’s about all the game has to offer in terms of content, but the game is actually pretty addicting and encourages competitive play and for you to pay extra attention to everything detail, especially when you start playing Arena.

Ricochet is very, very underrated and has a great and fun experience inside it especially with friends. It’s only $4.99 and is usually $0.99 during sales. I definitely recommend it if you’re looking for a really fun game to play with friends, or just want to experience a piece of Valve’s history.

reviewText:
Ricochet is an old-school multiplayer only game, an official Half-Life mod to be exact. The objective is to knock enemy players off of the board by throwing various projectiles (in the form of discs) at them, all of which have their own unique compounds and have to be collected around the map. The gameplay is simple, but when there are a fair number of people playing, it is fast paced and a lot of fun.

It was never really a popular game then and it is far from being any more popular now, but it is a lot of fun to play with friends. The servers are empty nine times out of ten so unless you actually have people to play with, it's not worth acquiring Ricochet.

Buy it only if you are capable of playing it to it's full potential and you will have fun.

reviewText: Across the myriad titles released in this game's generation and beyond, there has never been one quite as unique, quite as diverse, as Ricochet. In both style and execution, this game exceeds what the players, and, I think, the developers, had in store for the experience. It brings you into its world and immerses you in its culture from the very title screen, urging you to play more, to investigate, explore, and really see your environment from the viewpoint of your character. It does this not by throwing you into lengthy, drawn-out cinematics, but with control and movement unparalleled in any game to date, graphics unrivaled by even the largest of studios, and combat so immersive, so unmatched, that no other game can quite compare. No matter what advancements may visit videogames in the future, it's quite certain that Ricochet will always be a masterpiece, a paragon of ground-breaking gameplay and graphics, right up there with Dongers 3: The Revengening and Hello Kitty Island Resort: Uncensored Version.

Review: Ricochet definately stands out as an old Valve game. With the main menu, loading screens and the HUD, it's obvious that it is Valve once you launch it. I mean you can also see that it's Valve by scrolling down and looking at the developers and publishers (both Valve). This game is a fantastic concept. There are many servers, all with very few to no people playing. The gameplay mechanics are painful to learn and inact. It is definately NOT worth $4.99! For a game that was released in 2000, has many flaws, old graphics, and few people playing? I would definately not call it a rip off, but I would call it a failure. The game can be fun if you play it right, and to see a modernized version of this game would be great, but overall the game is not worth the price it's sold for, and the gameplay can get really repetative. The horrible sounds of your character falling into the void, over and over... Ugh... Anyway, if you DO want to get this game, you should get it in the Counter-Strike Anthology or Valve Complete Pack, or other packs, god knows what else they have... Don't get me wrong, this game is an amazing concept! If they would improve and make it worth our time, effort, and MONEY, it could be a great game. Overall, the game does not look completed, I could imagine so many features to this tron-styled game. I mean it's called 'Ricochet', and that's exactly what it is, glowing platforms in space, that you can jump off and ricochet onto others. Don't waste your time, unless you know exactly what you're getting.

Game Cons:

Old game
Broken mechanics
Unfineshed, and buggy
Terrible, old HUD
No people playing


Game Pros:

Fantastic Concept
Sometimes fun
Multiplayer works great
Goes by it's title

VALVe's mostly unknown experiment with the GoldSrc engine. This platform-esque shooter was the source of VALVes most hated projects, lauding it's ridiculous concept and lack of support.

Gameplay

Recommendations

Major

At first I thought it was something Valve employees made during one of their lunch breaks while developing Half-Life 1. Then I played it.

Well, apparently it is so. But that's not all there is to it.

Although Ricochet still looks like it was made in 20 minutes and is a Half-Life 1 mod, I managed to enjoy it immensely. As a stand-alone game, nah, it's not a masterpiece. As a lunch break filler, ironically, it is simply amazing. And is best with friends and voice chat.

That is, because of its original gameplay mechanics, and fast pace. You'll actaully spend quite some time to master it, and believe me, nothing feels better (during a lunch break). A great time killer if you ask me, though might not be for everyone. Graphics are obviously outdated, but that isn't exactly what you're looking for in this game. You're looking at them though. So, a 7/10 - would play during lunch break.

reviewText:
Ricochet is actually a pretty original idea, that did not get much success.

I believe there is 1 official map and the others are made by the community, but take my word as a grain of salt. I guess it is made really good for the game, that they did not feel the need to make any more, but who are we to judge the developers, maybe they just got bored out of the project after they saw that it ain't really popular. The gameplay isn't ordinary at all, but that is actually good, because it just adds variance to the First-Person genre, regardless if it works. You can only shoot in a horizontal line, you have 3 disks that behave somewhat like boomerangs and get back at you. Instead of pressing a button to jump, you have special pads across the map, so you can't jump whenever you want and the goal is to hit your enemies so they fall below the map and die.

I'd still recommend it, it has like 5 players at a time, but it's still a refreshing game.

When you get tired of playing laggy multiplayer, you want to play with some skilled bots. Nope. No bots. ♥♥♥♥ this game man.

reviewText:
Despite its simplicity, this game is quite fun. It's fun to bounce off of... bouncy bits and throw disc... things against... bumper things to knock that one prick off the stage. I only have a few real gripes with this:

-It can be difficult to find a server to play on
-The aforementioned bouncy bits have varying degrees of bouncyness, without any indication of what that bouncyness is. This means that there will be times when you expect to fly way over yonder when you only go down a floor.
-The additionally aforementioned disc things are effectively two dimensional, so you can't shoot at someone a floor above you, and vice versa. The bumper things are also very picky where you shoot them, so if you shoot your disc as soon as you go off the bumper, it's heading off to the vastness of space.

I found the power-up system to be enjoyable, but confusing to new players. To save you the trouble of figuring it out, I've prepared a little guide.

Note: You can have multiple power-ups and once.

-Power: Red Thingy: Decapitates people when you shoot them
-Fast Shot: Green Thingy: Lets you fire a flurry of discs at your opponent
-Triple Shot: Purple Thingy: Let's you fire three shots at once in three different directions. Useful for ricochet kills.
-Ice Shot: White Thingy: Turns victim into effective turtle on hit. Also seems to have slight homing properties from my experience.

5/6 Would play regularly
